turkish.text: Man is his own mirror.
A "bad" may have a "worse".
turkish.description: [but try to make the best of the current situation to prevent something worse from happening.]

turkish.text: A bachelor’s life is a lot of foolishness.
A bad neighbour forces you to have your own pots and pans.
turkish.description: [a reminder not to depend much on others, to become more self-reliant]

turkish.text: A bee knows which flower to take honey from.
turkish.description: [a smart person knows where his profit lies.]

turkish.text: A belly is nearer than a brother.
A big fish swallows up a small fish.
A bird flies in its own flock.
A bird is not taken with the hand.
A bird will not fly with one wing.
A boiling cauldron can’t keep a lid on.
turkish.description: [when the pot’s full, it will boil over.]

turkish.text: A boxwood comb for a bald head.
turkish.description: [used to make a point when someone indulges beyond his financial means.].

turkish.text: A building without foundation is soon demolished.
A calf of little worth is better than an ox in which you have only a share.
A camel might go to Mecca forty times, but that doesn’t make him a pilgrim.
A camel with bells is not lost.
A camel’s head does not pass through the eye of a needle.
A caravan does not turn back at the howling of a dog.
A chain is no stronger than its weakest link.
A cheerful wife is the joy of life.
A child is the fruit of a home.
A clever thief surprises the master of the house.
A covetous man serves his riches, not they him.
A cup of coffee commits one to forty years of friendship.
A day has an evening.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[every day ends with an evening.]

turkish.text: A debt is extinguished by force of paying, a journey by force of walking.
A debt is not paid with words.
A debt, of which there is no written acknowledgment, is not demanded.
A defeated wrestler is not tired of wrestling.
A desperate man will face many a risk.
A diamond, though men throw it in the mud, is still a diamond.
A dog fought with another dog and thus the traveler’s journey went smoothly.
A dog knows his master.
A dog that intends to bite does not bear its teeth.
A donkey does not appreciate fruit compote.
A doubtful bargain spoils the stomach.
A farmer’s granary lies at the tip of his plow.
turkish.description: [if you want a good harvest, till your fields as fits.]

turkish.text: A fish gets smart after it has gotten into the net.
A fool always rushes to the fore.
A fool dreams of wealth; a wise man, of happiness.
A fool finds no pleasure in understanding but delights in airing his own opinions.
A fool may sometimes speak to the purpose.
A forked peg will not enter the ground.
A friend is easier lost than found.
A friend is known on black [bad] days.
A friend is never known till a man have need.
A full purse is ones best companion.
A full purse never lacks friends.
A garden scarecrow is not a man.
A good companion shortens the longest road.
A good example is better than precept.
A good friend is shown in a black day.
A good man will appear when talked about.
A good maxim is never out of season.
A good wife is a good prize.
A goose and a girl are never satisfied.
A guest does not get the food he expects but what he’s served.
A guilty conscience feels continual tear.
A half-learned doctor can take your life; a half-learned priest can take your creed.
A halterless horse is not mounted.
A heart in love with beauty never grows old.
A heavy cauldron takes long to boil.
A heavy stone is not easily moved.
A horse is not caught with an empty sack.
A house is essential.
A house without a wife is like a safe without money.
A hungry bear does not play.
A hungry bear won’t dance.
turkish.description: [to work, one needs incentives that matter.]

turkish.text: A hungry hen sees herself in a wheat silo.
A hungry stomach has no ears.
A jealous head is soon broken.
A joke may easily become a serious matter.
A kind word warms a man throughout three winters.
A knife wound heals; a wound caused by words does not.
A knife-wound heals, but a tongue wound festers.
A lake forms drop by drop.
A lamb [sheep] away from the herd will be devoured by wolves.
A lion sleeps in the heart of every brave man.
A little bird is content with a little nest.
A little fire can light a lot of wood.
turkish.description: [it only takes a few troublemakers to upset the general peace.]

turkish.text: A little help is worth a deal of pity.
A little is better than none.
A low donkey is easy to ride on.
A man believes that he has been born, he does not believe that he will die.
A man deceives a man once.
A man does not become a savant by licking ink.
A man does not seek his luck, luck seeks its man.
A man had better have a good character rather than a handsome face.
A man is as wise as his head, not his years.
A man is born of his mother in order to die.
turkish.description: [the first breath is the beginning of death.]

turkish.text: A man is judged by his work.
A man is known by his company.
turkish.description: [every cat to her kind.]

turkish.text: A man is known by his friends.
A man is known by the company he keeps.
A man is to be feared from his speech, water from its floods.
A man who knows not what is good is not counted a man.
A man without a trade, a tree without fruit.
A meal prepared by others won’t be good, and besides it will be late.
turkish.description: [don’t rely so much on others.]

turkish.text: A mouse in time may shear a cable asunder.
A nail saves a horseshoe; a horseshoe saves a horse, a horse saves a rider and a rider saves a country.
turkish.description: [a small task may be part of the preparation for an important outcome.]

turkish.text: A nail will come out, but its hole remains.
A near neighbour is better than a far-dwelling kinsman.
A neighbor that is near is better than a relative of no benefit.
A neighbors hen looks as big as a goose, and his wife as young as a girl.
A old wolf does not lose his way.
A pear will fall to the root of the tree.
turkish.description: (children may turn out like their parents in more ways than one.)

turkish.text: A pear will fall to the tree’s root.
A person does not seek luck; luck seeks the person. – Turkish
A person who associates with scoundrels will acquire their habits.
A poor man has no friend.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[one that is unhappy has seldom friends.]

turkish.text: A pound is sixteen ounces wherever you go.
A promise comes from the mouth.
turkish.description: [an honourable person keeps his word.]

turkish.text: A proverb is an ornament to language.
A proverb is the wisdom of age and antiquity.
A quilt is not burnt to get rid of fleas.
A red apple invites stones.
A red shirt cannot be hidden.
turkish.description: [truth will out.]

turkish.text: A remedy without pain is not to be hoped for.
A rope breaks at a worn place.
turkish.description: [trouble begins at a weak spot.]

turkish.text: A shepherd cannot be made from a wolf.
A shepherd that is free from debt is better than a penniless prince.
A ship with two captains sinks.
A shop is not opened for the sake of one customer.
A single advantage is worth a thousand sorceries.
A single bad experience is worth a thousand threats.
A small key opens big doors.
A small leak will sink a great ship.
A snake is not taken with the hand.
A stitch in time saves nine.
A stone you would not have expected hurts your head.
A straightforward word is bitter.
A straw will show which way the wind blows.
A sweet tongue deceives many folks.
A thief is worthy of a scaffold and a criminal a dungeon.
turkish.description: [crime does not pay after time.]

turkish.text: A thief needs no key.
A thief passes for a gentleman when stealing has made him rich.
A thousand friends are too few; one enemy is one too many.
A thousand regrets do not pay one debt.
A tree is bent while it is young.
turkish.description: [add why and how too]

turkish.text: A tree without water gives no fruit.
A tribulation is better than a hundred warnings.
A true friend is better than relations.
A true word needs no oath.
A true word should never need any oath.
A twig is bent while it is green.
A village in sight does not require a guide.
A village that you can see in a distance do not require a guide.
turkish.description: [it is used to denote that events are heading to an obvious conclusion, so that further discussion may not be needed.]

turkish.text: A weapon is an enemy even to its owner.
A white day sheds light, and a black day sheds darkness.
A whole herd can take shelter in the shade of a great tree.
A wingless bird cannot fly.
A wise man does his own work.
A wise man is strong.
A wise man remembers his friends at all times; a fool, only when he has need of them.
A word is more valid than a signature.
A word to the wise is enough.
A worthy man is still worthy even penniless, a donkey is a donkey even if he is finely saddled.
A wrestler who is beaten can never get his fill of wrestling.
Ability has no school.
Abundance is from activity.
Act wisely and care not if you are called a fool.
Activity breeds prosperity.
Addictions are a curse.
After the conflagration ruins remain.
After the horse is stolen what remedy is it to lock the stable door?
turkish.description: [negligence causes loss.]

turkish.text: Age breeds aches.
Age is no barrier to learning.
Ale in, wit out.
All clouds bring not rain.
All hoods make not monks.
All is not lost that is delayed.
All lay loads on a willing horse.
All that glitters is not gold.
All work and no play will make such a dull boy.
An acorn one day proves an oak.
An apple a day keeps the doctor away.
An arrow once shot never comes back.
An ass does not appreciate fruit compote.
An ass is but an ass though laden with gold.
An athlete does not tell all his secrets.
An ember burns where it falls.
turkish.description: [used when expressing some sympathy for the pained people who are close to the injured or hurt person.]

turkish.text: An empty sack will not stand up.
turkish.description: [skills might help a person get along.]

turkish.text: An eye that sees something has some right.
An ignorant person is his own enemy, how can he be a friend to another?
An illness comes by the pound and goes away by the ounce.
An intelligent foe is better than a silly friend.
An old chicken produces a good soup.
An old fox understands the trap.
An old friend is a mount for a black day.
An open door invites callers.
An open enemy is preferable to a hidden friend.
An open mouth remains no hungry.
An ounce of luck is better than a pound of misery.
An unexpected stone can split the head.
An uninvited guest might not get a warm welcome.
Animals are governed by their reins; people by their, promises.
turkish.description: [words bind men.]

turkish.text: Appearance often deceives.
Appearances can be deceptive.
As soon as man is born he begins to die.
As you make your bed, so you must lie on it.
As you sow, so (shall) you reap.
Ask the banker about gold, the jeweler about gems.
At length the fox is brought to the furrier.
At table keep a short hand; in company keep a short tongue.
At the near end of the Long Market a man tells a lie, at the further end, he believes in it himself.
turkish.description: [to deceive oneself is easy, but not classy.]

turkish.text: Bad news is soon heard.
turkish.description: [travels quickly, – has wings.]

turkish.text: Barren ground should not be sown.
turkish.description: [don’t throw your seeds into the place where nothing grows.]

turkish.text: Be just before you are generous.
Be thine enemy an ant, see in him an elephant.
Beat the iron while it is hot.
Beautiful women give men a lot of trouble; they rob them and finally turn them into paupers.
Beauty alone is not enough.
Beauty and folly are often companions.
Beauty cannot be by force.
Beauty displays perfection.
Beauty fades like a flower.
Beauty may have fair leaves, yet bitter fruit.
Beauty passes, but perfection remains with us.
Beauty passes, wisdom remains.
turkish.description: [used to make a point: heed wisdom above physical beauty.]

turkish.text: Beauty won’t make the pot boil.
Before buying the cloth look at the sample; before marrying a girl look at her mother.
Beggar’s bags won’t be filled.
turkish.description: [some people don’t get enough fish.]

turkish.text: Believe no tales from an enemy’s tongue.
Better a calf of ones own than a jointly owned cow.
Better a dinner of herbs with love than a stalled ox where hate is.
Better a lean jade than an empty halter.
Better a wise foe than a foolish friend.
Better an egg today than a hen tomorrow.
Better are some small fish than an empty dish.
Better be a fool than a knave.
Better be half hanged than ill wed.
Better born lucky than wise.
Better go to heaven in rags than to hell in embroidery.
Better ride on an ass that carries me than a horse that throws me.
Better the crow I have than the nightingale others have.
Better to ask the way than go astray.
Better wit than wealth.
Between the cup and the lip a morsel may slip.
Between two stools you fall to the ground.
Beware of a returning arrow.
Beware of a silent man and still water.
Beware of an enemy, even though he be only an ant.
Beware of no man more than yourself.
Bread, unless it be chewed, is not swallowed.
Burn not your house to scare the mouse away.
Business opens business.
By renown and estimation the son of the noble is noble.
By the side of the dry the green [or wet] also burns.
turkish.description: [sometimes the innocent suffer along with the guilty.]

turkish.text: Carrion crows bewail the dead sheep, and eat them.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[he looks one way and rows another.]

turkish.text: Catch the bear before you sell its skin.
Charity begins at home, but does not have to end there
Children have wide ears and long tongues.
Coffee should be black as Hell, strong as death, and sweet as love. – Turkish
Common fame is seldom to blame.
Consult one who knows, but do what you know.
Contentment is an inexhaustible treasure.
Cotton cannot play with fire.
Counsel is irksome when the matter is past remedy.
Custom is nature to a man.
Cut off a dog’s tail and he will be a dog still.
Cut your coat according to your cloth.
Death in time of youth, poverty in time of age, are hard.
Desire is for the handsome and rich.
Destiny spoils plans.
Difficulties teach a man.
Distance is not taken by haste.
Do as you would be done by.
Do good, if you expect to receive it.
Do not be the partner of one more powerful than yourself.
Do not bring weariness to a council by having all the talk to yourself.
Do not dock the donkey’s tail in a crowd, some will say it’s too long, others it’s too short.
Do not leave to morning the business of evening.
Do not leave undone what is in your power to do.
Do not roll up your trousers before reaching the stream.
Do not search for a calf under an ox.
Do well and have well.
Do what your teacher says but not what he does.
Dogs bark but the caravan moves on.
turkish.description: [great achievements may not be prevented by barks.][whatever is done or said, it may have no significan’t effect on what happens or its the outcome]

turkish.text: Doing good to the evil is like doing evil to the good.
Don’t be captivated by beauty; look for disposition.
turkish.description: [a fragile gift is beauty.]

turkish.text: Don’t be deceived by the look of a book or a man, rather look inside.
turkish.description: [you cannot tell a book by its cover.]

turkish.text: Don’t believe in foretellings but don’t stay without them.
turkish.description: [some forms of foretelling, like prognoses and weather forecasts, hold benefits for different reasons.]

turkish.text: Don’t call every crooked branch your bow and don’t call everyone you see your uncle.
turkish.description: [don’t seize on the first thing that looks good.

turkish.text: Don’t change the sour milk you know for the butter milk you don’t know.
Don’t climb higher than your boot.
turkish.description: [said to one who meddles with things he does not understand.]

turkish.text: Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
Don’t cry for the moon.
Don’t cut off your nose to spite your face.
Don’t cut the bough you are standing on.
Don’t disclose your secret linen.
turkish.description: [don’t wash your dirty linen in public. wash your dirty linen at home.]

turkish.text: Don’t fall into a fire in order to avoid the smoke.
Don’t foul the well you have drunk from.
Don’t go into a matter you don’t understand.
Don’t go too far in something.
Don’t gossip while children are around.
turkish.description: [children have wide ears and long tongues.]

turkish.text: Don’t halloo till you are out of the wood.
Don’t let the box be opened; otherwise they will say bad things.
turkish.description: [if you bring up a certain subject you risk hearing unpleasant things.]

turkish.text: Don’t look at the envelope, but at what is inside.
turkish.description: [none can guess the jewel by the casket.]

turkish.text: Don’t look at the shape—look at the character.
Don’t play with edged tools.
Don’t promise what you cannot perform.
Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.
turkish.description: [have two strings to your bow.]

turkish.text: Don’t put your hand between the bark and the tree.
turkish.description: [i.e. don’t meddle in family quarrels.]

turkish.text: Don’t rely on a man, he may die; don’t lean on a tree, it may dry up, and don’t lean on a wall, it may fall down.
turkish.description: [if you trust before you try, you may repent before you die.]

turkish.text: Don’t roll up your trousers before reaching the stream.
turkish.description: [wait till you come to the river before you pull off your shoes.][one should not be overly eager and optimistic about an outcome.]

turkish.text: Don’t say you have wheat until it is stocked in the barn, and don’t say you have a son before you have experienced poverty.
Don’t strip off too many clothes, or you may get cold.
turkish.description: [don’t exceed your capabilities or you will suffer for it.]

turkish.text: Don’t take a heavy burden, otherwise you may hurt your back. Forecast is better than work-hard.
Don’t take for friends all who smile to your face.
Don’t tell your secret to your friend; he will tell it to his friend.
Don’t throw a lasso at stars in the sky.
turkish.description: [it is no use crying for the moon.]

turkish.text: Don’t try to teach your grandmother to suck eggs.
Drawn wells are seldom dry.
Dress up a stick, and it does not appear to be stick.
Drive your business, don’t let it drive you.
Drop by drop, it will make a lake.
turkish.description: [small savings can lead to substantial wealth. used to encourage people to save.]

turkish.text: Drunken days have their tomorrows.
Each brave man eats yogurt in his own way.
turkish.description: [everyone has his own way of doing things.]

turkish.text: Eagles don’t hunt flies.
Eat and drink with a friend, but have no business transaction with him.
Eat and drink with your friends but do not trade with them.
Eat peas with the king, cherries with the beggar.
Either drive this camel to pasture or leave the country.
Empty vessels make the most noise.
turkish.description: [a fool talks too much.]

turkish.text: Empty words don’t fill one’s stomach.
Empty words will not fill an empty stomach.
Envy eats nothing but its own heart.
Even if you know a thousand things, check it with an expert.
Even if you put a golden saddle on its back, a donkey is still a donkey. Though he endeavour all he can, an ape will never be a man.
Even the ant has his bite.
Even the cock is jealous concerning his hen.
Even the highest tree has an axe waiting at its foot.
Even too much praise is a burden.
Every bird admires its own nest.
Every bird loves to hear herself sing.
Every cock scratches around in his own garden.
Every cock will crow upon his own dunghill.
Every cook praises his own broth.
Every day of your life is a leaf in your history.
Every day the harm arising from carelessness is endured.
Every departure has an arrival.
Every ditch is full of afterwit.
Every door may be shut, but death’s door.
Every flower has a different smell.
Every man can rule an ill wife but him that has her.
Every man has a roll in his sleeve.
Every man has his faults.
Every man has his own way of eating yogurt.
turkish.description: [a reminder that others may have a different way of doing things, and hence asking for some tolerance.]

turkish.text: Every man likes his own things best.
Every misfortune is a counsel.
Every one is a lord in his own home.
Every one knows best where the shoe pinches him.
Every person admires his own character
Every potter praises his own pot.
Every rooster crows in its own pen.
Every sheep is hung by his own leg.
Every tub must stand on its own bottom.
Everybody beats the donkey that has no owner.
Everybody cries for his own dead.
Everyone admires his own character.
Everyone burns according to his own sins.
Everyone takes advantage of a mild person.
Everyone’s faults are not written on their foreheads.
Expect the worst, and any surprise will be a happy one.
Fair fall truth and daylight.
Fair without, false within.
turkish.description: [many are like that.]

turkish.text: Fair words butter no parsnips.
Fair words don’t fill the belly.
Fair words will not make the pot play
False friends are worse than bitter enemies.
Familiarity breeds contempt.
Fear an ignorant man more than a lion.
Fear does not empty tomorrow of its sadness; it empties today of its power.
Fear him who fears not God.
Fear takes molehills for mountains.
Feed a crow and it will pluck out your eyes.
Fetters of gold are still fetters. and silken cords pinch.
Few may play with the devil and win.
Fingers were made before forks.
First find your neighbour and then settle.
First impressions are most lasting.
First kill the bear then sell its skin.
turkish.description: [don’t sell the skin till you have caught the bear.]

turkish.text: First learn, then discern.
First think, then speak.
Fish begins to stink at the head.
Fit and good activity can breed prosperity in the long haul.
Flattery sits in the parlour when plain dealing is kicked out of doors.
For every wise man there is one still wiser.
For finding happiness one must walk till he be wearied.
For that which you can do yourself, rely not on another.
turkish.description: rely on yourself alone.

turkish.text: For the birds that cannot soar, God has provided low branches.
Forced beauty won’t quite do.
Fortune favours those who use their judgement.
Free vinegar is sweeter than honey.
Friends criticise, foes flatter.
Friendship and business are two different things.
Friendship is a plant that must be often watered.
From a base person comes no fidelity, from a harlot no shame.
From bad iron there cannot be a good saber.
Give advice to those who will heed your words and keep it in their ears (i.e. minds); don’t waste your breath on others.
Give nine, save ten.
God finds a low branch for the bird that cannot fly.
God gives according to the heart of each.
God has created us brothers but has given us separate purses.
God lets man sink but not be drowned.
God sends pine to those who ask for pine, and wax to those who ask for wax.
turkish.description: [seek your provision from above, and thank too]

turkish.text: Gold does not rust on the ground, and rocks don’t get soaked in the rain.
Gold takes no rust.
Good actions are not lost.
Good actions are rarely all lost.
Good advice is given, good esteem is not given.
Good bait catches fine fish.
Good clothes open all doors.
Good counsel may be given but not good breeding.
Good counsel may come too late to be of help.
Good deeds remain, all things else perish.
Good actions are never lost.
Goodness is better than skin deep beauty.
Grace could be natural.
Great oaks from little acorn grow.
Great vices, as well as great virtues, make men famous.
Guests bring good luck with them.
Gut no fish till you get them.
Habit is more dogged than rabies.
Habit is worse than rabies.
Hair will not grow on an egg.
Half a loaf is better than no bread.
Happiness comes from the health of soul.
Happy is he that is happy in his children.
Has there ever been a day without an evening?
turkish.description: [many good things must end at some time.]

turkish.text: Hasty climbers have sudden falls.
Hasty is the judgement of every fool.
Have two strings to your bow.
He beats his breast who does not beat his child.
He bites his tongue who speaks in haste.
He considers ill that considers not both sides.
He gives twice who gives quickly.
He is a fool that kisses the maid when he may kiss the mistress.
He is a good friend that speaks well of us behind our backs.
He is like a fish out of water.
He is wise that is ware in time.
He laughs best who laughs last.
He may give heartily who gives merely little.
He teaches ill, who teaches all.
turkish.description: [this is an advise not to tell the learner everything, or even a lot at once. and "a ladder is climbed rung by rung" is behind graded teachings too.]

turkish.text: He that comes first to the hill may sit where he will.
He that conceals his grief finds no remedy for it.
He that falls by himself never cries.
He that forecasts all perils will never sail the sea.
He that goes far to be married, will either deceive or be deceived.
He that handles thorns unawares may smart for it.
He that has done ill once will do it again.
He that is down need fear no fall.
He that is fallen cannot help him that is down.
He that is ill to himself will be good to nobody.
He that knows least commonly presumes most.
He that knows nothing, doubts nothing.
He that loves noise, must buy a pig.
He that mischief hatches, mischief catches.
He that prepares for ill, gives the blow a meeting and breaks its stroke.
He that respects not is not respected.
He that sows virtue, reaps fame.
He that speaks truth must have one foot in the stirrup.
He that strikes with his tongue must ward with his head.
He that thinks everyone is like himself is deceived.
He that travels far, knows how to.
He that travels far, knows much.
He that will be rich before night, may be hanged before noon.
He that will cheat at play, will cheat you anyway.
He that will eat the kernel, must crack the nut.
He that would be old long/well old, must be old betimes.
He that would have eggs must endure the cackling of hens.
He who at first suffers afterwards finds ease.
He who bears trouble patiently receives his reward.
He who borrows gets sorrows.
He who can’t bother to get married will have no children.
He who chastises not his children is himself at last chastised.
He who comes late shuts the door.
He who comes to the mill consents to his turn.
He who comes without invitation sits without cushion.
He who conceals his origin is a bastard.
He who cuts down a shoot cuts down someone’s head.
turkish.description: [a person needlessly cutting down trees is a killer of a sort.]

turkish.text: He who desires to have children must be willing to endure their hardships.
He who desires tranquility must be deaf, blind, and tongueless.
He who does evil to another, has done it to himself.
He who does evil to others, does it to himself.
He who dreads fire, guards himself even from smoke.
He who eats cheese finds water.
He who eats his crops when they are green will go hungry at harvest time.
turkish.description: [many sorts of vegetables are harvested when they are green, though.]

turkish.text: He who eats when he is full digs his grave with his teeth.
He who endures the trouble knows what it is.
turkish.description: [every one knows best where the shoe pinches him.]

turkish.text: He who enters a bath will sweat.
turkish.description: [everybody may bear the consequence of their acts.]

turkish.text: He who falls into the sea will grasp at an eel.
turkish.description: [a desperate man will face many a risk.]

turkish.text: He who gives fair words, feeds you with an empty spoon.
He who gives the money makes the fife play.
He who goes on a chase without a greyhound comes home without a hare.
He who goes out on a journey without a guide loses his way.
He who has bitter in his breast spits not sweet.
He who has had his mouth burnt is prudent on another occasion.
He who has many vineyards has many cares.
He who has no bread has no authority.
He who has no peace in his home, is in hell on earth.
He who helps the enemy is also considered an enemy.
He who is a man does not make a mistake twice.
He who is a traitor is a coward.
He who is hungry embraces the sword.
He who is wasting away with trouble must seek remedy.
He who keeps his head at home, loses not his hat in the crowd.
He who knows himself best esteems himself least.
He who knows not (i.e. fears not) God does not benefit from such as baldness.
He who laughs much, weeps much.
He who lives on hope dies of hunger.
He who marries early makes no mistake.
He who pays no heed to the words of his elders mounts a wild horse.
He who plants a walnut-tree may not eat of its fruit.
turkish.description: [it takes 6-8 years after the seedlings are planted, till the first walnuts appear. and some walnut trees don’t bear walnuts.]

turkish.text: He who puts a donkey up on a roof has to get it down again himself.
He who saves his ship is the captain.
turkish.description: [a clever man can weigh up the situation and gain quickly.]

turkish.text: He who sees death, consents to sickness.
He who sells cheap, sells quickly.
He who sends a child on an errand must go after him as well.
He who sets out on a journey without guidance loses his way.
He who sleeps with a blind man will wake up cross-eyed.
He who speaks much, errs much.
He who takes no thought at first will at the last repent.
He who throws a stone at his relatives will never prosper, give the kinsman his due.
turkish.description: [charity begins at home, but which home?]

turkish.text: He who wants a mule without fault must walk on foot.
He who would catch fish must not mind getting wet.
He who would hang his dog gives out first that it is mad.
He whom the heart loves is the handsome one.
He whose account is clean will have a happy face.
turkish.description: [happiness comes from the health of soul.]

turkish.text: Health and wealth create beauty.
Health is better than wealth.
Health is not valued till illness comes.
Hear much, speak little.
High places have their precipices.
Himself an old man in need of help, how can he help another?
His actions speak themselves.
His bark is worse than his bite.
Hoist your sail when the wind is fair.
Hold fast when you have it.
Hope for the best and prepare for the worst.
Hope often deludes the foolish man.
How we live [co]determines how we die.
However lean the meat may be, it goes well upon bread.
However much snow falls, still it does not endure summer.
Hunger makes the wolf come out of the forest.
I have rather an ass that carries me than a horse that throws me.
I would rather have an donkey that carries me than a horse that throws me.
"If’ and "when" were planted, and "nothing" grew.
If a dog’s prayers were answered, bones would rain from the sky.
If a man anticipated his death, he would dig his own grave.
If a stone falls on an egg, it is bad for the egg; if an egg falls on a stone, it is still bad for the egg.
If a tree afford you shade, don’t cut it down. When the tree falls, the shade is gone.
If and When were planted and Nothing grew
If cats had wings, sparrows would become extinct.
If everyone were of the same mind, there couldn’t be a shepherd for sheep.
If everyone were of the same mind, there would be no market in Bilecik.
If everyone would go to heaven, hell would be empty.
If I spit downward, (I defile) my beard; if upward, my mustache.
turkish.description: [it is a difficult situation.]

turkish.text: If skill could be gained by watching, every dog would become a butcher.
If the bald knew a remedy he would rub it on his own head.
If the carriage be not greased, it does not move on.
If the dog’s prayer were accepted, there would be a shower of bones from heaven.
If the head be left empty, it is not well.
If the insolent man is strong, the one in the right is considered guilty.
If the partridge had the woodcock’s thing, it would be the best bird that ever fly. Speak without ifs and ands.
If the wind does not blow, the leaves do not move.
If the world is flooded, it will be easy for the duck.
If violence comes by the door, law goes out by the chimney.
If we have not money, let us have honor.
If wishes were butter cakes, beggars might bite.
If you are an anvil, be patient; if you are a hammer, be strong.
If you cannot bite never show your teeth.
If you corner a cat, it will jump on you.
If you deal with a fox, think of his tricks.
If you do not know what to say, say what your elders said.
If you don’t know how to swim, why are you at the seashore?
If you give him cloth, hell ask for the lining.
If you have fallen, then cling to the ground.
If you have wicked children, of what use is money; and if good, again, of what use is it?
If you leap into a well, providence is not bound to fetch you out.
If you lie down with hogs, you will get up with fleas.
If you look after it it will become a vineyard; if you don’t, a barren field.
If you speak the truth, keep a foot in the stirrup.
If you trust before you try, you may repent before you die.
If you wish to do a good deed, consult no one.
If you wish to know a man, give him authority.
If your head be without pain don’t thrust it into trouble.
turkish.description: [when you are well hold yourself so.]

turkish.text: In a flat country a hillock thinks itself a mountain.
In a great river, great fish are found, but take heed to avoid getting drowned.
In an office of trust there must be no treachery.
In every business be steadfast.
In fair weather prepare foul.
In for a penny, in for a pound.
In many words, a lie or two may escape.
In proportion as anger comes, sense departs.
In the absence of qualified men, the ignorants will rule.
In the estimation of the nightingale, a cage of gold is a prison.
In the heart of every brave man a lion sleeps.
In the place where the cat is not found, there are plenty of rats.
In the place where there are many cocks, the morning is early.
In the presence of an expert a lie is not uttered.
In the spot where honey is, flies too are found.
In truth is right.
Incline not toward those who do wrong lest the fire touch you.
Instead of having a handful of gold, it [could be better] to have a handful of earth (i.e. a piece of land).
Instead of opening your mouth, open your eyes.
Intelligence is a man’s capital.
Intelligence is not sold for money.
Iron that works does not rust.
turkish.description: [one has to practise to keep up one’s performance.]

turkish.text: Iron with use grows bright.
Isn’t another’s example enough for you?
turkish.description: [one man’s fault is another man’s lesson.]

turkish.text: It could be better to have an ugly husband than none.
It has snowed on trees with red cherries.
turkish.description: [even very unlikely things sometimes happen.]

turkish.text: It is a bad bird that fouls its own nest.
It is a good thing to listen to the words of one woman in forty.
It is a long road that has no turning.
It is a poor heart that never rejoices.
It is an ill bird that fouls its own nest.
It is better to be born lucky than rich.
It is better to misplace our charity on nine unworthy persons than to deny alms to one that is really in need.
It is easier to make a camel jump a ditch than to make a fool listen to reason.
It is easy for a bachelor to divorce a wife.
turkish.description: (said to a person who demands to be helped out of a difficulty for which he himself is responsible.)[from a safe port one can luckily advise comfortably.]

turkish.text: It is easy to catch a serpent with someone elses hand.
It is easy to say Come difficult to say Go.
It is good to be merry and wise.
It is good to listen to the words of one woman in forty.
It is good to strike the serpent’s head with your enemy’s head.
It is hard to teach an old dog tricks.
It is more difficult to contend with oneself than with the world.
It is no play where one greets [weeps] and another laughs.
It is not by saying, Honey, honey, that sweetness comes into the mouth.
It is not disgraceful to ask, it is disgraceful not to ask.
It is not how long, but how well we live.
It is not in speaking continually of honey that sweetness comes into the mouth.
It is not what is eaten but what is digested that nourishes the body.
It is proper that the tongue of a debtor be short.
It is the first step that is troublesome.
It is the human tongue which makes tremble both man and beast.
It is the squalling child that gets the milk.
It is too late to husband when all is spent.
It is too late to spare when the bottom is bare (when all is spent).
It matters less to a person where they are born than where they can live.
It may be better to have honour than wealth.
It’s easy to be wise after the event.
Jack of all trades would teach his grandma a howling wolf had quiet depths.
Justice is the aider of the upright.
Justice watches the eye like a bird.
Keep guard over the tongue that is in your mouth.
Keep straw, its time will come.
Keep your eyes open: a sale is a sale.
Keep your mouth shut and your ears open.
Kill not the goose that lays the golden eggs.
Kind words will unlock an iron door.
Kiss the hand which you cannot wring.
Know your own faults before blaming others for theirs.
Know yourself.
Knowledge without practice makes but half an artist.
Laugh, and the world would laugh with you; weep, and you weep alone.
Lawful property is not lost.
Laziness keeps on and on, but it arrives at poverty.
Learn not and know not.
Leave a jest when it pleases you best.
Lend only that which you can afford to lose.
Let another’s shipwreck be your seamark.
Let bygones be bygones.
Let the cobbler [shoemaker] stick to his last.
Let’s wait and see how things will turn out in the morning.
turkish.description: [it could be better to do things in the morning, if fresh, rested and in good shape, if time allows it.]

turkish.text: Life is half spent before we know what.
Like hen, like chicken.
Like loves (likes) like.
turkish.description: [a jackdaw always perches beside another of its kind.]

turkish.text: Listen a hundred times; ponder a thousand times; speak once.
Listen to others, but use your own mind.
Little by little we become fat.
Little pigs have big ears.
Little pitchers have big (great) ears.
Little sins make room for great.
Little thieves are hanged, but great ones escape.
Live and learn.
Long absence changes a friend.
Long life has long misery.
Look at the mother before marrying the daughter.
turkish.description: [observe the mother before you take the daughter.]

turkish.text: Look before you leap.
Look not at the shape, look at the character.
Look to yourself when the neighbour’s house is on fire.
Love and a king accept no partnership.
Love is an empire-it admires no partnership.
Love is daring.
Love is lawless.
Love is the mother of all godliness.
Love me, love my dog.
Love your friend, but look to yourself.
Love your neighbour, yet don’t pull down your hedge.
Mad people think others mad.
Make haste in buying land, but not in taking a wife.
Make hay while the sun shines.
Make no one an enemy without cause.
Man is harder than iron, stronger than stone and more fragile than a rose.
Manners make the man.
Many a little make a mickle.
Many ants kill a camel.
Many will show the proper way after the carriage (variant: ox cart) has overturned.
turkish.description: [many seem to be wise with advice after the event.]

turkish.text: Many will show you the way once your cart has overturned.
Many will throw stones at red apples.
Marriage is no playhouse.
May both seller and buyer see the benefit.
May God grant one luck of the ugly.
May your charity increase as much as your wealth.
Maybe the bottom will turn out better than the top.
Measure a thousand times and cut once.
Measure is treasure.
turkish.description: [sound moderation (sound measure) in many things helps.]

turkish.text: Measure twice, cut but once.
Men are not all alike.
Men love to hear well of themselves.
Men make houses, women make homes.
Mercy to the criminal may be cruelty to the people.
Mere talk does not satisfy the stomach.
Mischief comes not from a friend.
Misfortune arrives on horseback but departs on foot.
Money covers blame.
Money does not always help.
Money is needed both by monk and dervish.
Money will come to one who trusts in his art [Art and craft].
Much talk makes no money.
Music befits a house where there is a wedding.
Never answer a question until it is asked.
Never catch at a falling knife or a falling friend.
Never cross a bridge till you come to it.
Never do business with a relative.
Never hit a man when he’s down.
Never judge from appearance.
Never marry for money, you’ll borrow it cheaper.
Never swap horses in midstream.
Never trifle with love.
Never trust a spiteful man.
Never venture out of your depth till you can swim.
No day so clear but has dark clouds.
No flock without dog and shepherd.
No forest without a bear.
No home is complete without a woman.
No man is his craft’s master the first day.
No matter how far you have gone on a wrong road, turn back.
No matter how far you have gone on the wrong road, it’s time to stop.
No matter how far you have gone on the wrong road, turn back.
No matter how much snow falls, it won’t remain there all the way till summer.
No matter how tall a tree grows its leaves always fall to the ground.
No matter where you go, your destiny follows you.
No rose without a thorn, or a love without a rival.
No smoke will come out from a place where there is no fire.
No sound comes forth from a single hand.
None so blind as those that will not see.
Not every fault is to be reminded.
Not every flower is for smelling.
turkish.description: [it may not be discerning to flirt with every pretty girl around.]

turkish.text: Not every one’s inner self and outer appearance are the same. Everyone’s faults are not written on their foreheads.
Not every tree produces fruit.
Not everything that shines is gold.
Nothing enters into a close hand.
Nothing has no savour.
Now is now, and then was then.
Of all crafts, to be an honest man is the master craft.
Of every perfection there is a decline.
Of everything else the newest; of friends, the oldest.
Of prayer there must be acceptance.
Of savings comes having.
Old age is sickness of itself.
Old birds are not caught with chaff.
Old churches have dim windows.
Old shoes are easiest.
Old sins cast long shadows.
Old vessels must leak.
Old young, young old.
turkish.description: [i.e. if a person seems oldish in his childhood, he may become childish in his old as if to make up for it.]

turkish.text: Once a friend, always a friend.
One armpit cannot hold two watermelons.
One arrow does not bring down two birds.
One bad person harms seven districts.
One by one we count the beans.
One calamity is better than a thousand counsels.
One can never repay ones debt to ones mother.
One can not carry two watermelons under one armpit
One can rarely be too careful.
One can’t enter heaven by worshiping, one needs to have a pure heart.
One cannot be a lover by force.
One cannot eat the cake and have it.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[you cannot have it both ways.]

turkish.text: One cock is enough for five hens.
One cup of wine takes away the whole of a person’s bashfulness.
One does not burn a blanket to get rid of a flea.
One does not cut cloth for a yet unborn child.
turkish.description: [a caution not to invest or risk a lot based on assumptions.]

turkish.text: One does not descend into a well by a rotten rope.
One does not despair of desires.
One doesn’t need a guide to a village that is in sight.
One foot is better than two crutches.
One good forewit is worth two afterwits.
One good turn deserves another.
One guest loves not another guest; the master of the house dislikes both.
One is equally indebted to ones teacher and to God.
One is often blind to the faults in one’s own work.
One man’s fault is another man’s lesson.
One man’s loss is another man’s gain.
One may know by your nose what pottage you love.
One must ask the delight of opium from one that smokes it.
One must do a job after careful thinking.
One must look at a man’s company.
One must treat inferiors with reserved politeness, or probably they will take liberties.
One nail drives out another.
One needs muscles of iron to fight against love.
One neighbor’s fowl seems a goose to another neighbor.
One pays for what one does.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[as they brew, so let them drink.]

turkish.text: One rotten apple soon spoils the whole basket.
One scabbed sheep will mar the whole flock.
One scabby sheep mars the whole flock.
One searches for someone else’s donkey while singing songs.
One should measure a thousand times and cut once.
turkish.category: turkish proverbs[you may be too careful.]

turkish.text: One should not betray a trust.
One topic leads to another.
One who handles honey, licks his fingers.
turkish.description: [somebody in charge of handling money or resources, may enjoy some benefits from it.]

turkish.text: One who is afraid of debts does not open his door wide.
turkish.description: [a person who wants to avoid debts is careful with his expenses and with his generosity.]

turkish.text: One’s mouth is nearer than that of a dear one.
Opportunities mean rubies.
Opposition to everyone is a mistaken act.
Other times, other manners.
Our neighbour’s ground yields better corn than ours.
turkish.description: [said to be a common distortion – fairness and candid observation may be called for, unless it is used humorously.]

turkish.text: Part with your head, but not with your secret.
Patience is bitter, but it bears sweet fruit.
Patience is safety, haste is blame.
Patience is the key of joy.
Patience is the key to paradise.
Pear, get ripe and fall right into my mouth.
turkish.description: [you may have to gape a while before it happens.]

turkish.text: Peasant erect is taller than peasant on bended knee.
People are masters over people till arriving at the throne of God.
Pigs might fly if they had wings.
Plan your work for winter and if it turns out to be summer, count it a blessing.
turkish.description: [expect the worst, and any surprise will be a happy one.]

turkish.text: Plant good seed, and don’t suffer from hunger.
Plant pears for your heirs.
Planting trees is as blessed an act as raising children.
Poison is poison though it comes in a golden cup.
Poor folks are glad of porridge.
Poverty is a shirt of fire.
Practice makes perfect.
Praise is not pudding.
Praises fill not the belly.
Press not the tail of a sleeping snake.
Prettiness makes no pottage.
Prevention is better than cure.
Prick yourself with a needle first before you stick a darning needle into others.
Profit is the brother of loss.
Prosperity makes friends, adversity tries them.
Proverbs are the children of experience.
Proverbs are the daughters of daily experience.
Put your foot down where you mean to stand.
Put your hand no further than your sleeve will reach.
turkish.description: [spend according to your income.]

turkish.text: Quiet persons are welcome everywhere.
Refrain from getting involved in something that hasn’t been well thought out.
Remain hungry but do not start begging.
Remember the dog and have your stone ready.
turkish.description: [if you’re going to deal with an aggressive person, you ought to be ready for a fight.]

turkish.text: Remove an old tree and it will wither to death.
Repentance comes too late.
Resignation is fitting for destiny.
Reversing losses at whatever point will benefit you.
turkish.description: [used to help folks to take better directions than going down or astray, or taking a wrong path.]

turkish.text: Riches alone make no man happy.
Riches are for spending.
Rose without thorns, love without rival, cannot be.
Roses grow where a teacher hits.
Rumour is a lying jade.
Running water takes no defilement.
Salt enters into all food.
Satisfaction of the heart is better than wealth.
Save a stranger from the sea, and he’ll turn your enemy.
Say little but to the point.
turkish.description: [speak words straight to the point.]

turkish.text: Say nothing but think the more.
Scratch my back and I’ll scratch yours. One good turn deserves another.
Season resembles not season.
Seeing is believing.
Seeing once is better than reading a thousand times.
Seek that which may be found.
Seek truth in meditation, not in moldy books. Look in the sky to find the moon, not in the pond.
Self-praise is no recommendation.
Serving one’s own passions is the greatest slavery.
Shallow streams make the most din.
Sharp vinegar may damage its container.
turkish.description: (it is said to calm down or moderate a person.)

turkish.text: Show pity to the lowly, obedience to the lofty.
Sickness shows us what we are.
Silence comes from admission.
Silks and satins put out the fire in the chimney.
Slander leaves a score behind it.
Sleep is the excuse of sleep.
Sleep over it.
Sleepless nights shorten one’s life.
Slow but sure wins the race.
Some are wise and some are otherwise.
Soon ripe, soon rotten.
Sorrow will pay no debt.
Spare the rod and spoil the child.
Speech is silence, silence is golden.
Stairs are climbed step by step.
Step after step the ladder is ascended.
Storm in a walnut shell
Stretch out your legs according to your quilt.
turkish.description: [spend according to your income.]

turkish.text: Stretch your feet according to your blanket.
turkish.description: [one often does well to spend within one’s means.]

turkish.text: Strike while/when the iron is hot.
Study from new books but from old teachers
Such music, such people.
Suit your comb to your beard, and search and find the one you will be happy with throughout your life.
Sweet things are bad for the teeth.
Sweetness charms the soul.
Take many counsellors, but don’t abandon the counsel of your own heart.
Take the currycomb and go into the stable, the one with the saddle gall will flinch.
turkish.description: [when there is an investigation, a guilty person may betrays himself by nervous fidgeting and anxiety.]

turkish.text: Taking counsel is a noble precept.
Tell me who your friend is, and I’ll tell you who you are.
turkish.description: [tell me what company you keep, and i’ll tell you who you are.]

turkish.text: Tell me your company and I’ll tell you your manners.
That which is far from the eye is far from the heart.
"The grapes are sour," the fox said when he could not reach them.
The account of the donkey is different from the account of the donkey-man.
The angry beggar is left with an empty bag.
turkish.description: [poverty and anger don’t agree.]

turkish.text: The apple never falls far from the tree.
The arrow that is shot returns not back.
The ass that has not enough strength throws down his pack saddle.
The bad neighbour forces one to have one’s own pots and pans.
The barrel smells after the first wine.
The bears in the mountains eat the best of pears.
The bee stays not in a hive that has no honey.
The best laid plans fail.
The best of words are spoken as jokes.
turkish.description: [many a true word is spoken in jest][many an earnest word is spoken in jest.]

turkish.text: The best remedy against an ill man is much ground between.
The best throw of the dice is to throw them away.
The bird flies not without cause.
The bird is known by his note, the man by his words.
The biter is sometimes bit.
The blackness of soot is cleaned, but the blackness face (i.e. shame) is not.
The branch shows the tree.
The brave dies, his name remains.
The bright coin is kept for dark days.
turkish.description: [money saved can come to one’s rescue in a time of need.]

turkish.text: The butcher minds the fattening, but the goat the slaughter.
The buyer repents, the seller also repents.
The camel carries the burden, the dog does the panting.
The camel never sees its own hump, but that of its brother is always before its eyes.
The camel that leads the file pays no attention to the rear.
The cat cannot catch the hare.
The cat would eat fish but dislike to wet its feet.
The command of custom is great.
The condition of the lover is evident from his words and expressions.
The cord breaks at last by the weakest pull.
The cow knows not what her tail is worth till she has lost it.
The cow that has died used to give a lot of milk.
The cure for old age is the grave.
The devil looks after his own.
The devil takes a hand in what is done in haste.
The devil tempts all other men, but idle men tempt the devil.
The devil wipes his tail with the poor man’s pride.
The dog barks and the caravan passes on.
The dog bites not his master.
The dog knows the hand that gives him bread.
The dog that knows not how to bark brings the wolf to the sheep.
The donkey’s plan is different from than that of the rider’s.
The early bird gets the worm.
The earth has ears, it hears every word.
The egg of today is better than the fowl of tomorrow.
The elephant is bigger than the camel.
The end of every disgraceful action is repentance.
The end of haste is repentance.
The excellence of a man is a benefit to the public.
The eye sees only what it has the power of seeing.
The eye that sees all things else doesn’t see itself.
The eyes are the window of the soul.
The eyes of the bat are hurt by the light.
The face of an official is cold.
The first step is the hardest.
The fish is caught from the head.
The fish stinks from the head.
The fly is small, but it is big enough to make one sick.
The fool continues procrastinating, the wise man waits a fit occasion.
The foreigner attaches a handle to an egg.
The fox comes forth from a hole you would not have expected.
The frog saw how the horses were shod, so she also lifted up her foot.
The gardener, for the sake of one rose, becomes the servant of a thousand thorns.
The girl should be married off while she has suitors.
The goat drank wine and went up the mountain to look for wolves.
The goat has a beard too.
The gold being gone, let us look to the silver.
The granary is at the point of the plowshare.
The great thieves hang the little ones.
The greatest step is that out of doors.
The green twig is easily bent.
The grocer does not open his shop for the sake of one customer.
The ground has ears.
turkish.description: [fields, hedges, and woods and walls, all have ears.][meaning: be careful so that unwanted listeners may not overhear you.]

turkish.text: The hand that gives is above that which receives.
The hare is in the mountain, but the soup water is on the fire.
turkish.description: [the situation may soon change.]

turkish.text: The hated man seldom ends well.
The hazelnut emerged from its shell and did not like the look of it.
The head that bends is not cut off.
The head that is cut off does not shoot again.
The horse ambles according to his master.
The house that receives no guests, never receives angels.
The hungry ass runs more strongly than the horse.
The hungry dog does not push on in the chase.
The hungry man is not satiated by looking in the face of the full man.
The hunter in the chase is like the traveler on a journey.
The ignorant person is like a cock out of season.
The jeweler knows the value of jewels.
The keen sword cuts not its scabbard.
The kick of a quiet horse is hard.
turkish.description: [the quiet man’s anger can get most dangerous.]

turkish.text: The knife cuts not its sheath.
The knife does not make the cook.
The law gives sentence on what is apparent.
The leeful man is the beggar’s brother.
The lion is known by his den.
The lion is valiant, the leopard treacherous.
The little hill of a low district becomes a mountain.
The lover walks in the snow and does not make his tracks visible.
The lover who suffers not anguish knows not the worth of pleasure.
The master of the house is the servant of his guest.
The master’s eye is a groom for the horse.
turkish.description: [if the owner of a business cares about its keys of success, his workers might also do a good job.]

turkish.text: The master’s eye makes the cow fat.
The middle of every thing is good.
The mill cannot grind with the water that is past.
The mill won’t turn with carried water.
The miser and the open-handed spend the same in the long run.
The moon does not heed the barking of dogs.
The more one knows, the less one believes.
The mosquito is without a soul, but its whizzing vexes the soul.
The mouse that has but one hole is quickly caught.
The mouth is not worn away by dint of talking.
The mouth of a young bird is big.
The multitude is like a flock of sheep.
The nightingale was put in a golden cage, but it cried for its home. Freedom is better than gold.
The nose of him whose guide is a crow will never get out of the shit.
The old fox does not fear the trap.
The one who asks has one side of his face dark; the one who refuses to give has both sides dark.
turkish.description: [used to put the shame or burden on the side that can give but refuses to do so.]

turkish.text: The one who burns his mouth for drinking milk too hot, eats even yogurt carefully.
turkish.description: [experiences teach people to be more cautious.]

turkish.text: The one who enters a Turkish bath is in for sweating.
turkish.description: [on bearing consequences of one’s choices somehow.]

turkish.text: The owl thinks all her young ones beauties.
The parents’ trade remains an inheritance to the children.
The pear falls not far from its tree.
The physician prescribes the medicine, the vulture waits for the body.
The place of your birth is less important than how you live.
The plumber’s toilet always leaks. A defeated wrestler is not tired of wrestling.
The polite man has learned from the unpolite.
The poor man seeks for food, the rich man for an appetite.
The priest does not eat pilaff every day.
The priest likes a dead man.
turkish.description: [everyone is wrapped up in his own concerns.]

turkish.text: The quietness of the cat lasts till he sees the mouse.
The raven sees its chicks as falcons.
The real friend tells the bitter truth.
turkish.description: [used to soften the blow when a friend needs to give some unpleasant advice.]

turkish.text: The rich mans wealth tires the poor man’s jaw.
The rotten apple injures its neighbours.
The saber cuts not its own scabbard.
The sage speaks of what he sees; the fool, of what he hears.
The sea is an emperor that listens to no words.
The sea never buys fish.
The seashore is never free of waves.
turkish.description: [some places seem to attract waves, or trouble.]

turkish.text: The shame of a bald man is hidden by the cap.
The sheep separated from the flock can get eaten by the wolf.
turkish.description: [used to encourage a person to keep a useful and classy network and group somehow.]

turkish.text: The ship of him who confides in God founders not.
The shroud has no pockets.
turkish.description: (spend your wealth wisely and do good before wearing one.)

turkish.text: The snake issues from a hole you would not have supposed.
The snake, unless he be straightened out, cannot enter his hole.
The son of a wolf will be a wolf, even if he grows up with man.
The sparrow has no song, but plenty of twitter.
The stairs are mounted step by step.
The stone of patience cracked.
turkish.description: [there may be a limit to one’s patience.]

turkish.text: The stone that lies in your gate won’t break your toes.
turkish.description: [i.e. the stone that doesn’t lie in my way need not offend me.]

turkish.text: The strength of a chain is in the weakest link.
turkish.description: [a chain is no stronger than its weakest link.]

turkish.text: The submitting to one wrong brings on another.
The teeth of a gift horse are not inspected.
The testimony of the heart is stronger than a hundred witnesses.
The testimony of the liar is not accepted.
The thief is sorry he is to be hanged, but not that he is a thief.
The thing which is rare is dear.
turkish.description: [it often happens.]

turkish.text: The thread breaks where it is weakest.
turkish.description: [trouble begins at a weak spot.]

turkish.text: The tide must be taken when it comes.
The tongue slays quicker than the sword.
The tool does the work but the hand is proud of it.
turkish.description: [the real work is often done by people who don’t get the credit for it.]

turkish.text: The tool works, the hand boasts.
The true worth of a person comes out when he is working.
The truth can be told even in jest.
The use of certain markers on these page is for easing the reading. At the bottom part of of pages is a link to explanations of the markers.
The village that is in sight needs no guide.
The village that one can see requires no guide.
The vulture catches not the fly.
The wasp makes not honey.
The wealth of the world is not reliable.
The wolf and the sheep cannot be of one mind.
The wolf catches not the sheep that are counted.
The wolf catches the sheep that separates from the flock.
The wolf changes his skin, but not his nature.
The wolf eats of the sheep that have been warned.
The wolf enters a flock that is without a dog.
The wolf may lose his teeth, but never his nature.
The woolly sheep is easy to shear.
The workman is known by his work.
The world is a large inn, he who settles there also moves away.
The world is ruined by tyranny, it is not ruined by pickaxe and spade.
The world’s coin is ingratitude.
The worst wheel of the cart creaks the most.
The worth of a thing is best known by the want of it.
The worth of gold is due to its scarcity.
turkish.description: [ – as for yellow corn, its abundance too.]

turkish.text: The wound of the hand heals; the wound of the tongue heals not.
The young cock crows as he hears the old one.
There are friends and friends.
turkish.description: [different sorts of friends, and maybe so-called friends also.]

turkish.text: There are many who fall into the misfortunes of their companions.
There are many who throw stones at a red apple.
turkish.description: [something of value may not be riskily exposed.]

turkish.text: There cannot be a general without soldiers.
There comes nought out of the sack but what was there.
There is a madman in every house, but in our house everybody is mad.
There is a scorpion under every stone.
There is an uphill for every downhill, and a downhill for every uphill.
There is comfort in changing of places.
There is no axe that cannot penetrate a tree.
There is no friend to a man like his mother.
There is no fruit from a dry tree.
There is no garden without its weed.
turkish.description: [poison seems to do away with "weeds", but at a price.]

turkish.text: There is no grape without a stalk.
There is no lake without frogs.
There is no one in the world without pain.
There is no rose without thorns.
There is no rule without an exception.
turkish.description: [what about this one?]

turkish.text: There is no shame in learning.
There is no sovereignty like bachelorhood.
There is no trust in horse or woman.
There is not a single season without fruit.
There is nothing lost by civility.
turkish.description: [often. with senseless civility it may be different.]

turkish.text: There must be a handle to an axe.
There will be a day when laughter comes to mourners.
There’s naught so queer as folk.
They asked for vinegar from he who claimed that his vinegar was forty years old; his answer was "If I had given to all who asked for it, would I still have vinegar of forty years?"
They asked the camel why its neck was curved. "What of me is straight?" it said.
They asked the Turkmen whether he wants to buy bees, he said Why should I have all that buzz with my money?
They call "past" a thing that is past.
They call you "generous" and make you lose your property, they call you "brave" and make you lose your life.
turkish.description: [watch out, accordingly.]

turkish.text: They put the nightingale in a golden cage, it still craved for its country.
turkish.description: proverbs[golden cages and golden fetters are signs of inherently menial conditions. what about the nobility?]

turkish.text: They put up minds for sale on the market, everyone liked his own mind.
They throw stones at a tree with fruit.
turkish.description: (the trees that bear fruit are stoned to make fruits fall down and be taken.)(the good and talented may be envied and criticised a lot.)

turkish.text: They told the poor man it was snowing, and he said "I’m ready to shiver."
turkish.description: [the poor get hardships.]

turkish.text: They who are skillful in art do not continue in slipper making.
They who guard against treachery are few.
They who live longest, [may] see most.
They will soon enough cut off the head of a cock that crows before it is time.
Things are not always what they seem.
Things never go so well that one should have no fear, and never so ill that one should have no hope.
Think first and speak afterwards.
Think on the end before you begin.
This world is the unbeliever’s paradise.
Thorns and roses grow on the same tree.
Those aspiring to higher positions must be equipped with enough talent or equipment, or otherwise foolish ambition may be the cause of their downfall.
Those who know do not talk; those who talk do not know.
Those with a vineyard in the hill have a burning brand in their hearts.
turkish.description: [having properties don’t mean you are free from cares and worries.]

turkish.text: Though speech be silver, yet silence is gold.
Though the proverb is abandoned, it is not falsified.
Though the rain fall for forty years it does not pass into marble.
Time stays not the fool’s leisure.
Timidity prevents progress.
To a bachelor, divorcing a wife comes easy.
turkish.description: [the outsider may lack significan’t or telling information.]

turkish.text: To a lover, melancholy is no shame.
To be forewarned is to be forearmed.
To be penitent at long last is no use.
To deceive oneself is very easy.
To die full is better than walking in hunger.
To do good to an ungrateful man is to throw rosewater in the sea.
To exceed is as bad as to fall short.
To pull even a single hair from a pig is a gain.
turkish.description: [a stingy or unfriendly man.]

turkish.text: To speak of honey will not make the mouth sweet.
To the big-mouthed the ladle is a spoon.
To the wise, the noise of a gnat suffices, to the unwise the sound of a bass drum not.
To work without payment is better than sitting idle.
Today a good cheer, tomorrow on the bier.
Today to me but tomorrow to you.
Today’s egg is better than tomorrow’s hen.
Today’s fowl is better than tomorrow’s goose.
Tomorrow is another day.
Too late to cut a stick when the fight is over.
Too many cooks make the porridge too salty.
Too many cooks spoil the broth.
Too much barley makes the horse burst.
Too much hope deceives.
Too much kindness is of no profit to a child or man.
Too much kindness to a man is not profitable, for he becomes ungrateful.
Too much of a thing can be good for nothing.
Too much sympathy with the unfortunate makes you unhappy.
Tread not on a rotten plank.
Trust is a mother of deceit.
Trust is good, but distrust is better.
Trust not a woman when she weeps.
Trusting too much to others is the ruin of many.
Truth breeds hatred.
Two blacks don’t make a white.
Two captains cause one ship to sink.
Two captains sink the ship.
Two cocks won’t crow on the same dunghill.
Two dogs do not share one bone.
Two heads are better than one.
Two horses are not tied to one stake.
Two swords do not enter one scabbard.
Two watermelons do not go under one armpit.
United we stand, divided we fall.
Unless a job is begun, it can never be finished.
Unless the oven is hot, bread will not bake.
Unless there be a sowing there will be no reaping.
Until a man dies his value is not known.
Until the soup boils over, the ladle has no value.
Use makes mastery.
Venture a small fish and catch a great one.
Verdicts are pronounced according to the way the matter is presented.
turkish.description: [the result depends on how the case is presented.]

turkish.text: Vigilance and precaution are safety.
Vinegar at a cheap rate is sweeter than honey.
Violence spoils the game.
Virtue shows itself.
Vows made in storms are forgotten in calms.
Waiting is more grievous than fire.
Wake not a sleeping lion.
Walls have ears.
Want of wit is worse than want of wealth.
Water flows to the low ground.
Water is not carried out in a sieve.
"We always advance," says the tortoise.
We are living in a time when people are after money.
We may give advice, but we cannot give conduct.
We plant walnuts and pears for our heirs.
We soon believe what we desire.
Wealth and success don’t just come to a man on a silver platter.
Wealth can be both a friend and an enemy to a man.
Well is, that well does.
What business does a dog have in the shop of the blacksmith.
What cannot be cured must be endured.
What is the use of a gold basin to a person coughing up blood?
turkish.description: [money does not always help.]

turkish.text: What makes a tree beautiful is its leaves.
What news do you have beside bad news?
What one thousand scholars may not know, one wise man may know.
What the elder sister wears, the younger sister wants to wear also.
What the eye doesn’t see, the heart doesn’t grieve over.
What the eye sees the heart wants.
turkish.description: [we soon believe what we desire.]

turkish.text: What we first learn, we best can.
What will be, will be.
Whatever the thoughts of the dervish, so are his actions.
When a drunkard gets sober, he starts thinking.
turkish.description: [drunken days have their tomorrows.]

turkish.text: When a man grows angry, his reason rides out.
When a pine tree falls, men gather around both with and without axes.
turkish.description: [people like to profit by or enjoy a great man’s fall.]

turkish.text: When an opportunity is in your hand do not allow it to pass.
When death comes, the dog presses up to the wall of the mosque.
When fortune smiles, embrace her.
turkish.description: [cf. when fortune knocks, open the door (german, italian).]

turkish.text: When in Rome, do as the Romans (do).
When justice comes, that which is false goes.
When one door shuts, another opens.
When one’s shoes are tight the world becomes tight on one’s head.
When the belly is full, the bones would be at rest.
When the bundles of tobacco are ready, dancing begins.
When the carriage has been smashed, they who show the road are many.
When the cat is away, the mice will play.
When the heart is a fire, some sparks will fly out of the mouth.
When the horse dies, the foal takes its place.
When the well is full, it will run over.
When the wine is in, the wit is out.
When two jars are dashed together, one must be broken.
When you are well hold yourself so.
When you tell the truth, have one foot in the stirrup.
Where the front wheels a the carriage passes, the hind wheels follows.
Where there is carcass, there are also crows.
Wherever the head goes, the foot also goes.
While the tree is a sapling it is bent.
White clothes soon get dirty.
Who buys cheap buys dear.
Who desires the rose must also consent to the thorns.
Who enters the Turkish bath will sweat.
Who fears the sparrows must not sow millet.
Who gossips to you will gossip about you.
Who has a fair wife, needs more than two eyes.
Who has never been burned in the sun won’t know the value of a shadow.
Who has no beard has no authority.
Who has no intention to pray has no ears for the call to prayer.
Who is in fault suspects everybody.
Who keeps company with the wolf, will learn to howl.
Who loves roses will endure the thorns.
Who nothing has shall nothing save.
Who seeks a friend without faults, dies alone.
Who sets off on a journey without any provisions, will have his both eyes on another’s bag.
Who takes the devil for a comrade, a bad comrade has he. [The Koran]
Who trusts to rotten boughs, may fall.
Whoever digs a pit for his neighbor should dig it his own size.
Whoever is fond of cream should take the cow around with him.
Whoever speaks evil to you of others will speak evil of you to others.
Whoever the heart loves, she is the beauty.
Wholesome and poisonous herbs grow in the same garden.
Why keep a cow when you can buy milk?
Wife and children are bills of charges.
Wish well, be well.
With foxes one must play the fox.
With haste catch a fly.
With one arrow two birds are not struck.
With patience the cocoon of the moth on the mulberry leaf is made into a silk gown.
With patience the sour grape becomes sweet and the mulberry leaf, satin.
With patience, mulberry leaves become satin.
With talking the cheese ship won’t move.
Without a guide, even into Paradise there is no entering.
Without hammering there is no fastening.
Without provisions, one does not start upon a journey.
Without wisdom wealth is worthless.
Womankind is long haired, short witted.
Words are but wind, but seeing’s believing.
Work as if you were to live forever; live as if you were to die tomorrow.
Work is not his who does it, but his who makes others do it.
Work is the mirror of a person, don’t look at mere words.
Worse things happen at sea.
You can tell a lion from where he dwells / you can tell what kind of a lion he is by his lair.
turkish.description: [you learn a lot about a person if you see how well his home is kept.]

turkish.text: You can tell that the customer wants a shroud just by looking at his face.
You can’t expect a good thing to go on for ever.
You can’t make a spoon out of just any wood.
turkish.description: [it takes the right person and/or materials to do a job right.]

turkish.text: You cannot get blood out of a stone.
You cannot know the wine by the cask [or barrel].
You cannot lose what you never had.
You cannot make a crab walk straight.
You cannot make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear.
You cannot please everyone.
You cannot pluck roses without fear of thorns, nor enjoy a fair wife without danger of horns.
You don’t wash blood away with blood but with water.
You harvest what you sow.
You may have too much of a good thing.
You may visit your aunt, but not very frequently.
You must lose a fly to catch a trout.
You must not expect old heads on young shoulders.
You never know till you have tried.
You reap where you have sown.
You should make sure that you are perfect before you make fun of the imperfections of others.
You sometimes come back to your first love.
Young men’s knocks old men feel.
Your work of the day is your sleep
The most difficult master is the servant who became master.
What a man suffers is the punishment of his tongue.
Man is harder than iron, stronger than stone and more fragile than a rose.
Even if the whole world conspired against you — that would not inflict a quarter of the harm you inflict yourself.
The thief can lie, those he has stolen from cannot.
You don’t steal a bitter eggplant.
He who steals honey, licks his fingers.
Who has power in his hands has no need to lie; he uses violence.
A single bad experience is worth more than a thousand threats.
If you weep for all the sorrows in this world, in the end you will have no eyes.
Your five year old son is your instructor; at ten your slave; at fifteen your equal and after that either friend or foe.
If the lady of the house breaks something it is an unfortunate accident; if the servant does, then it is a terrible disaster.
The gardener who loves roses is slave to a thousand thorns.
Keep the tongue in your mouth a prisoner.
Satan’s friendship reaches the prison door.
Sorrow is to the soul what the worm is to wood.
He who has no children has one sorrow, he who has children has a thousand sorrows.
No matter how far you have gone on a wrong road, turn back.
A knife wound heals; a wound caused by words does not.
Gold that is lent goes away laughing and comes back in tears.
If your beard’s on fire, others will light their pipes on it.
The physician prescribes the medicine, the vulture waits for the body.
To live in peace one must be blind, deaf, and mute.
No fat mouse in a widow’s house.
An ass does not appreciate fruit compote.
From lean meat do not expect fat broth.
Silence is music to a wise man.
A true word needs no oath.
He that speaks truth must have one foot in the stirrup.
You can proclaim the truth also in a friendly way.
When God wants to please a poor man, He lets him lose his donkey and then helps him find it again.
Even though you know a thousand things, ask the man who knows one.
You don’t have to know much to read, but you do to cook.
He, who knows much makes many mistakes.
Don’t say amen to an unacceptable prayer.
Everyone admires his own character.
Don’t look at the shape — look at the character.
The real capital of a man is a mirror worth two cents.
He, who controls his tongue, saves his head.
If a man would live in peace he should be blind, deaf, and dumb.
Good actions are never lost.
If you look for a faultless woman, you will remain a bachelor.
Who seeks a faultless friend remains friendless.
Things that are weak will break, as men do who think they are strong.
God made low branches for birds that cannot fly so well.
Men make the earth black from green leaves.
One night with an ugly woman and one day in the mountains both are like an eternity.
The rose comes from the thorns that were born of roses.
Where conceit and ignorance sit, grass will not grow again.
The earth has ears, the wind has a voice.
Before you love, learn to run through snow, leaving no footprints.
No matter how much snow falls, it won’t remain there all the way till summer.
Don’t sell the fish that is still swimming in the ocean.
The sea never buys fish.
The account of the donkey is different from that of the donkey-man.
The first drink makes you a frisky gazelle, the second an impetuous zebra, the third a roaring lion, and with the fourth you become a silly donkey.
The eagle does not feed on flies.
The raven sees its chickens as falcons.
To a good rider, right or left makes no difference.
To quote lies is also lying.
A liar’s house is on fire and no one believes him.
A single advantage is worth a thousand sorceries.
A man will sacrifice his head to conquer a heart.
He who asks for alms blushes once; he who refuses, twice.
Don’t ask an innkeeper the way.
There are many words that are like salted jam.
Don’t speak sweet words when your deeds are of stone.
The cheese vessel will not sail merely by words.
Cruelty is stupidity.
A stupid friend is a greater plague than a wise enemy.
Listen with both ears, but speak with only one tongue.
A prudent man will read the letter from back to front.
The fool sings a love song to his wife; the wise man will talk about his dog.
One hour of justice is worth seventy hours of prayer.
When violence comes into the house, law and justice leave through the chimney.
Heaven was inspired by the first judge to take a bribe.
In the company of the blind, close your eyes.
A heart in love with beauty never grows old.
Before you love, learn to run through snow without leaving footprints.
Who kisses the feet of his mother, kisses the step of Paradise.
You cannot get into Paradise without a guide.
Idle men tempt the devil; the devil tempts all others.
The devil tempts all other men, but idle men tempt the devil.
If you search for a faultless woman, you will remain a bachelor.
A building without foundation is soon demolished.
What flares up fast, extinguishes soon.
Never become a teacher where you yourself were a pupil.
He that falls by himself never cries.
Who burned himself with hot milk blows on ice-cream.
Death is the black camel that kneels before every door.
Coffee should be black as Hell, strong as death, and sweet as love.
One arrow does not bring down two birds.
Do not leave to the morning the business of the evening.
Two captains sink a ship.
If your guest becomes a cook, your larder will soon be empty.
No matter how far down a wrong road you are, turn back.
A single bad experience is worth a thousand threats.
